title: Psalms Chapter 87 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 87 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 87 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 87.

questions.question: Where is the foundation of the Psalmist according to Psalms 87:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The holy mountains
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:1 states that the foundation is in the holy mountains.

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:2, which does the LORD love more?
questions.correctAnswer: The gates of Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 says the LORD loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.

questions.question: What kind of things are spoken of the city of God according to Psalms 87:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Glorious things
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:3 states that glorious things are spoken of the city of God.

questions.question: Which places are mentioned in Psalms 87:4 as known by the Psalmist?
options: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 mentions Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia.

questions.question: What will be said of Zion according to Psalms 87:5?
options: This and that man was born in her
questions.correctAnswer: This and that man was born in her
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 says it shall be said of Zion that this and that man was born there.

questions.question: Who shall establish Zion according to Psalms 87:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The highest himself
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 declares that the highest himself shall establish Zion.

questions.question: What will the LORD do when he writeth up the people according to Psalms 87:6?
options: Count that this man was born there
Write only the names of kings
questions.correctAnswer: Count that this man was born there
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 says the LORD shall count when he writeth up the people that this man was born there.

questions.question: Who shall be there together according to Psalms 87:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Singers and players on instruments
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 states that both singers and players on instruments shall be there.

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:7, where are all the springs?
questions.correctAnswer: In thee (Zion)
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 says all my springs are in thee, referring to Zion.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 87:2 says the LORD loves the dwellings of Jacob more than the gates of Zion.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 states the LORD loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob, not the reverse.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 87:4, the Psalmist speaks of Ethiopia as a place where a man was born.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 includes Ethiopia as one of the places where a man was born, mentioned by the Psalmist.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 87:1 describes the foundation as being in the valley of Jericho.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:1 says the foundation is in the holy mountains, not in the valley of Jericho.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 87:3: 'Glorious things are spoken of thee, O ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: city of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:3 says, 'Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:6, what does the LORD do when He writes up the people?
options: Counts that this man was born there
questions.correctAnswer: Counts that this man was born there
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 explains that the LORD counts when He writeth up the people that this man was born there.

questions.question: Who is the Psalm or song for according to Psalms 87:1?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Korah
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:1 identifies this Psalm as a Psalm or Song for the sons of Korah.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 87 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 87 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:1 teach us about the importance of a strong spiritual foundation in our daily walk with God?
options: Our foundation should be in the holy mountains, symbolizing a life rooted in God's presence
Our foundation should be built on worldly success and riches
Our foundation is irrelevant as long as we believe in God
Our foundation should be in personal opinions and traditions
questions.correctAnswer: Our foundation should be in the holy mountains, symbolizing a life rooted in God's presence
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:1 states, 'His foundation is in the holy mountains,' emphasizing the need for a firm spiritual foundation rooted in God's holiness, which supports faith, obedience, and perseverance (Psalms 87:1; also supported by Psalms 87:3, 87:7).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement in their service at church. Based on Psalms 87:2, what biblical truth about God's love can encourage them?
options: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob
God only loves those who are perfect in their service
God's love depends on how much we achieve
God's love is only for certain nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 affirms God's special love for Zion, symbolizing His people and church, encouraging believers to trust in His steadfast love despite challenges (Psalms 87:2; Psalms 87:5).

questions.question: What does Psalms 87:3 teach about the reputation and witness of a city or community grounded in God?
options: Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God
A city with wealth is always glorious
Only large cities can have a good reputation
A city’s reputation depends on its political power
questions.correctAnswer: Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:3 highlights that a city founded on God’s presence bears a glorious testimony, encouraging believers to cultivate a godly witness in their communities (Psalms 87:3; Psalms 87:7).

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:4, how should believers view people from different backgrounds in the context of God's kingdom?
options: God acknowledges people from diverse nations like Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
Only people from one nation can belong to God
Believers should avoid those from other nations
God’s kingdom is exclusive to a single ethnic group
questions.correctAnswer: God acknowledges people from diverse nations like Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 mentions various nations, illustrating God’s inclusive grace and the call to evangelism, encouraging believers to embrace and witness to all peoples (Psalms 87:4; Psalms 87:5).

questions.question: How can Psalms 87:5 encourage believers in their identity and security in God's family?
options: The highest himself shall establish her, affirming God's sovereign establishment of His people
Believers must earn their place in God's family by works
Identity in God depends on social status
God’s family is uncertain and unstable
questions.correctAnswer: The highest himself shall establish her, affirming God's sovereign establishment of His people
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 assures that God, the highest, establishes Zion, symbolizing the security of believers founded on God’s sovereignty, fostering humility and contentment (Psalms 87:5; Psalms 87:6).

questions.question: What practical lesson about God's record-keeping and personal identity can be drawn from Psalms 87:6?
options: The LORD counts and writes up people, affirming each believer's recognized place
Only leaders are recorded by God
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD counts and writes up people, affirming each believer's recognized place
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 shows God’s personal knowledge and acknowledgment of each believer, encouraging faith, perseverance, and integrity in daily life (Psalms 87:6; Psalms 87:5).

questions.question: In Psalms 87:7, what does the presence of singers and players on instruments in Zion teach about worship in the life of believers?
options: Worship through music is a vital expression of spiritual life and joy
Worship is only about silent prayer
Worship should be done individually only
questions.correctAnswer: Worship through music is a vital expression of spiritual life and joy
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 mentions singers and instrumentalists in Zion, highlighting the importance of worship and fellowship in the believer’s spiritual discipline and church life (Psalms 87:7; Psalms 87:3).

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:2 encourage believers to trust God in their family and church relationships?
options: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob
Family ties are more important than God’s love
Trust should be placed in human leaders only
Church relationships are secondary to personal ambition
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 affirms God’s special love for His spiritual family, encouraging believers to prioritize faith, love, and service within the church community (Psalms 87:2; Psalms 87:7).

questions.question: A believer feels isolated and questions their place in God's family. Based on Psalms 87:6, what truth would you share to encourage them?
options: The LORD counts and records every person born in Zion, affirming their identity
Only the perfect are counted by God
Believers can lose their place easily
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD counts and records every person born in Zion, affirming their identity
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 reassures that God acknowledges and records each person, which encourages believers to persevere and find contentment in their secure identity in Christ (Psalms 87:6; Psalms 87:5).

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:4 inspire believers regarding evangelism and reaching out to others?
options: God includes many nations, showing the call to share the Gospel broadly
Evangelism is only for certain people
Outreach is unnecessary since God only loves one group
questions.correctAnswer: God includes many nations, showing the call to share the Gospel broadly
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 mentions various nations being known and included by God, encouraging believers to share their faith across cultural boundaries (Psalms 87:4; Psalms 87:3).

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:7, what role does joyful worship play in sustaining believers through trials?
options: Joyful worship, with singing and instruments, refreshes the soul and strengthens faith
Worship should be somber and joyless
questions.correctAnswer: Joyful worship, with singing and instruments, refreshes the soul and strengthens faith
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 highlights the presence of music and singing in Zion, encouraging believers to use worship as a source of encouragement and perseverance in trials (Psalms 87:7; Psalms 87:3).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 87 teaches that God’s love and acceptance are limited to the descendants of Jacob only.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 shows that God acknowledges many nations including Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia, illustrating God's inclusive love beyond Jacob's descendants (Psalms 87:4; Psalms 87:2).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 87, God’s establishment of Zion is dependent on human efforts.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 states that 'the highest himself shall establish her,' indicating that God sovereignly establishes Zion, not human efforts (Psalms 87:5; Psalms 87:6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 87:7 says, 'As well the singers as the players on instruments shall be there: all my _________ are in thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: springs
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 uses 'all my springs are in thee,' symbolizing that the source of life and joy flows from God’s presence, encouraging believers to find contentment and spiritual refreshment in Him (Psalms 87:7; Psalms 87:3).

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:3 encourage believers to maintain a godly witness in their communities?
options: Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God
Believers should isolate themselves from the community
Good reputations depend on worldly status
Communities do not impact personal faith
questions.correctAnswer: Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:3 teaches that a godly community bears a glorious testimony, motivating believers to live with integrity and share the Gospel (Psalms 87:3; Psalms 87:4).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 87 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 87.

questions.question: What is described as having its foundation in the holy mountains according to Psalms 87?
questions.correctAnswer: The city of God
questions.explanation: Verse 1 says, 'His foundation is in the holy mountains,' referring to the city of God, which is Zion.

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:2, what does the LORD love more than all the dwellings of Jacob?
questions.correctAnswer: The gates of Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 2 explicitly states, 'The LORD loveth the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.'

questions.question: Which of the following cities is NOT mentioned in Psalms 87:4 as being spoken about to those who know God?
questions.correctAnswer: Nineveh
questions.explanation: Verse 4 mentions Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia but does not mention Nineveh.

questions.question: In Psalms 87, who is identified as the one who will establish Zion?
questions.correctAnswer: The highest himself
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states, 'and the highest himself shall establish her,' referring to God as the highest.

questions.question: What role does the LORD play according to Psalms 87:6 when He writeth up the people?
options: He counts those born in Zion
questions.correctAnswer: He counts those born in Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 6 says, 'The LORD shall count, when he writeth up the people, that this man was born there,' emphasizing divine registration of natives.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'As well the singers as the players on __________ shall be there: all my springs are in thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: instruments
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states, 'As well the singers as the players on instruments shall be there,' highlighting musical worship.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 87 associates the city of God with multiple foreign nations, indicating a universal scope.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 4 mentions Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia, showing a universal inclusion in Zion's identity.

questions.question: The term 'Rahab' in Psalms 87:4 is often interpreted as a poetic name for which nation?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: In biblical poetry, 'Rahab' frequently symbolizes Egypt, as seen in Isaiah and Psalms, aligning with the context of foreign nations.

questions.question: Which literary device is most prominent in Psalms 87:3 with the phrase 'Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, praising Zion with exalted expressions.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'all my springs are in thee' in Psalms 87:7 in a theological context?
options: It symbolizes the source of life and blessing in Zion
It refers to literal water springs in Jerusalem
It denotes the origin of the sons of Korah
It describes the natural resources of the land
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the source of life and blessing in Zion
questions.explanation: The phrase metaphorically represents Zion as the spiritual fountain and origin of God's blessings.

questions.question: How does Psalms 87 reflect the theme of inclusion of Gentiles into God's people?
options: By naming foreign nations as born in Zion
By excluding all nations except Israel
By emphasizing only the sons of Korah
By focusing solely on the holy mountains
questions.correctAnswer: By naming foreign nations as born in Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 4 and 5 mention various nations and individuals born in Zion, indicating God's inclusive covenant.

questions.question: Psalms 87 is attributed to which group of worship leaders or authors?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Korah
questions.explanation: The superscription in verse 1 indicates it is a Psalm or Song for the sons of Korah, a guild of temple singers.

questions.question: The mention of 'Babylon' in Psalms 87:4 serves as a literary symbol for what in the broader biblical context?
options: A symbol of exile and foreign power
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of exile and foreign power
questions.explanation: Babylon often symbolizes exile and opposition to God’s people, highlighting the psalm's theme of reconciliation and inclusion.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 87 foreshadows New Testament teachings about the inclusion of Gentiles in God's kingdom?
options: The birth of individuals from foreign nations in Zion
The exclusive love for Jacob’s dwellings
The foundation in the holy mountains
questions.correctAnswer: The birth of individuals from foreign nations in Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 4-5 anticipates the New Testament theme of Gentiles becoming part of the people of God by birth or adoption.

questions.question: What is the authorial intent behind emphasizing that 'the highest himself shall establish her' in Psalms 87:5?
options: To affirm God's sovereign authority over Zion
To highlight the sons of Korah's role
questions.correctAnswer: To affirm God's sovereign authority over Zion
questions.explanation: The phrase underscores God's supreme role in establishing and maintaining Zion, reflecting divine sovereignty.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 87 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 87 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is described as having its foundation in the holy mountains according to Psalms 87?
questions.correctAnswer: The city of God
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:1 states that His foundation is in the holy mountains, referring to the city of God, symbolizing the spiritual and eternal foundation of God's dwelling place. This is consistent with Isaiah 2:2 and Hebrews 12:22 where God's holy city is established on a holy foundation.

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:2, what does the LORD love more than all the dwellings of Jacob?
questions.correctAnswer: The gates of Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 clearly states the LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob, emphasizing God's special affection for Zion, the spiritual center and place of His presence. This is echoed in Zechariah 8:3 and Psalm 48:2 where Zion is called the city of the great King.

questions.question: Which nations are mentioned in Psalms 87:4 as being recognized by God in relation to the city of God?
options: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:4 mentions Rahab (a poetic name for Egypt), Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia as nations known by God in connection with the city of God, indicating the inclusion of Gentiles in the divine plan. This aligns with Isaiah 56:6-7 and Acts 10:34-35 where Gentiles are included among God's people.

questions.question: What will be said about Zion according to Psalms 87:5?
options: This and that man was born in her
She shall be destroyed no more
The LORD will forget her not
questions.correctAnswer: This and that man was born in her
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 declares that many individuals will be said to have been born in Zion, signifying spiritual birth and belonging to God's people. This speaks to the doctrine of adoption and regeneration (John 1:12-13, Galatians 4:26, Revelation 21:2).

questions.question: Who is said to establish Zion according to Psalms 87:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The highest himself
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:5 states that 'the highest himself shall establish her,' referring to God the Most High, affirming His sovereign and divine authority in establishing Zion. This aligns with Psalm 2:6 and Isaiah 33:20 where God is depicted as the ultimate establisher of His city.

questions.question: What does the LORD do when He writeth up the people according to Psalms 87:6?
options: He counts that this man was born there
questions.correctAnswer: He counts that this man was born there
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 emphasizes God's personal record-keeping of His people, counting them as born in Zion, which reflects the doctrine of election and God's intimate knowledge of His redeemed (Psalm 147:4, Luke 10:20, Revelation 20:12).

questions.question: According to Psalms 87:7, who shall be present in Zion?
questions.correctAnswer: Singers and players on instruments
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:7 states that both singers and musicians will be there, symbolizing worship and praise in the presence of God, which reflects the eschatological hope of joyful praise in God's eternal kingdom (Revelation 5:8-9, 1 Chronicles 15:16, Psalm 150:3-6).

questions.question: What is the significance of the mention of Rahab in Psalms 87:4?
options: It represents Egypt as part of God's inclusive plan
It refers to a Canaanite woman converted to faith
It symbolizes the destruction of enemies
It indicates a geographical boundary of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It represents Egypt as part of God's inclusive plan
questions.explanation: In Psalms 87:4, Rahab is a poetic name for Egypt, showing God's recognition of Gentile nations and their inclusion in His salvation plan. This theological inclusion is affirmed in Isaiah 19:25 and Romans 11:25-26, emphasizing God's mercy beyond Israel.

questions.question: What theological truth about God's people is emphasized by the statement in Psalms 87:5 that 'this and that man was born in her'?
options: Spiritual birth and inclusion in God's covenant community
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual birth and inclusion in God's covenant community
questions.explanation: This phrase in Psalms 87:5 refers to spiritual birth signifying believers' adoption into God's family, consistent with John 3:3-5, Galatians 3:26-29, and 1 Peter 2:9 where believers are born anew and become God's chosen people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:2 illustrate God's special relationship with Zion in contrast to Jacob's dwellings?
options: God loves the gates of Zion more than all dwellings of Jacob
God favors all Jacob's dwellings equally
God is indifferent to Zion compared to other dwellings
God condemns all other dwellings outside Zion
questions.correctAnswer: God loves the gates of Zion more than all dwellings of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:2 highlights God's particular love for Zion, demonstrating His covenantal focus on the city as the spiritual center. This is supported by Psalm 132:13-14 and Jeremiah 3:17 where Zion is uniquely favored by God.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is conveyed by the presence of singers and musicians in Zion as mentioned in Psalms 87:7?
options: Joyful worship in God's eternal kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Joyful worship in God's eternal kingdom
questions.explanation: The presence of singers and musicians in Psalms 87:7 symbolizes the eternal worship in God's kingdom, as seen in Revelation 5:9-13 and Isaiah 35:10, where redeemed believers praise God perpetually.

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed in Psalms 87:6 regarding His knowledge of His people?
options: Omniscience in counting and recording His people
questions.correctAnswer: Omniscience in counting and recording His people
questions.explanation: Psalms 87:6 reveals God's omniscience and personal involvement in knowing and recording His people, consistent with Psalm 147:4-5 and Luke 12:7 which affirm God's intimate knowledge of His children.

questions.question: What does the mention of 'all my springs are in thee' in Psalms 87:7 symbolically represent?
options: The source of life and blessings in Zion
The natural resources of the land
questions.correctAnswer: The source of life and blessings in Zion
questions.explanation: This phrase in Psalms 87:7 metaphorically indicates that all spiritual blessings and life flow from Zion, aligning with John 7:38 and Isaiah 12:3 where living water and blessings come from God’s presence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 87:4's mention of foreign nations contribute to the biblical theology of salvation?
options: It reveals God's plan to include Gentiles in His covenant people
It restricts salvation to Jews only
It predicts the destruction of these nations
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals God's plan to include Gentiles in His covenant people
questions.explanation: By naming Rahab, Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, and Ethiopia, Psalms 87:4 points to the inclusion of Gentiles within God's people, consistent with Isaiah 56:6-7, Ephesians 2:11-22, and Galatians 3:28 where salvation is extended beyond Israel.

questions.question: What messianic theme can be inferred from the phrase 'the highest himself shall establish her' in Psalms 87:5?
options: God the Father establishing His kingdom through the Messiah
The human king building the city walls
The angels guarding the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: God the Father establishing His kingdom through the Messiah
questions.explanation: The 'highest himself' refers to God’s sovereign power, which in biblical theology is fulfilled in the Messiah who establishes God's kingdom, as seen in Psalm 2:6-8 and Luke 1:32-33.
